message_1:
Consider the matrix A =  \begin{bmatrix} 2 & -1 & 0 \\ 4 & 3 & -1 \\ -2 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}. 

Find a diagonal matrix D and an invertible matrix P such that A = PDP⁻¹.
message_2:
To find the diagonal matrix D and the invertible matrix P, we first need to find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of matrix A.

The characteristic equation of A is given by:

|A - λI| = 0

where λ is the eigenvalue and I is the identity matrix.

Expanding the determinant, we get:

|(2-λ)(3-λ)(1-λ) - (-1)(-1)(-1)| = 0

(λ-1)(λ^2 - 5λ + 6) = 0

The eigenvalues are λ1 = 1, λ2 = 2, and λ3 = 3.

Now, we find the eigenvectors corresponding to each eigenvalue:

For λ1 = 1:

(A - λ1I)X = 0

\begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1 & 0 \\ 4 & 2 & -1 \\ -2 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}X = 0

The eigenvector corresponding to λ1 = 1 is X1 = [1, 1, 2]^T.

For λ2 = 2:

(A - λ2I)X = 0

\begin{bmatrix} 0 & -1 & 0 \\ 4 & 1 & -1 \\ -2 & 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix}X = 0

The eigenvector corresponding to λ2 = 2 is X2 = [0, 0, 1]^T.

For λ3 = 3:

(A - λ3I)X = 0

\begin{bmatrix} -1 & -1 & 0 \\ 4 & 0 & -1 \\ -2 & 0 & -2 \end{bmatrix}X = 0

The eigenvector corresponding to λ3 = 3 is X3 = [1, -1, 2]^T.

Now, we can construct the diagonal matrix D and the invertible matrix P:

D = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 3 \end{bmatrix}

P = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & -1 \\ 2 & 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}

To verify that A = PDP⁻¹, we can compute PDP⁻¹ and check if it is equal to A:

PDP⁻¹ = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & -1 \\ 2 & 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & -1 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}

PDP⁻¹ = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & -1 & 0 \\ 4 & 3 & -1 \\ -2 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}

Since PDP⁻¹ = A, we have found the diagonal matrix D and the invertible matrix P such that A = PDP⁻¹.
